message_1: A spaceship is traveling at 0.8c (80% of the speed of light) and fires a proton beam towards a target in front of it. What energy will the proton beam have when it hits the target, assuming it was initially at rest with respect to the spaceship? Use the equation for relativistic kinetic energy to calculate the answer.
message_2:
To calculate the energy of the proton beam when it hits the target, we need to use the equation for relativistic kinetic energy:

K = (γ - 1)mc²

where K is the kinetic energy, γ (gamma) is the Lorentz factor, m is the mass of the proton, and c is the speed of light.

First, we need to find the Lorentz factor (γ) for the spaceship traveling at 0.8c. The Lorentz factor is given by:

γ = 1 / √(1 - v²/c²)

where v is the velocity of the spaceship. In this case, v = 0.8c.

γ = 1 / √(1 - (0.8c)²/c²)
γ = 1 / √(1 - 0.64)
γ = 1 / √(0.36)
γ = 1 / 0.6
γ ≈ 1.667

Now that we have the Lorentz factor, we can calculate the kinetic energy of the proton beam. The mass of a proton is approximately 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg.

K = (γ - 1)mc²
K = (1.667 - 1)(1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg)(3 × 10⁸ m/s)²
K ≈ 0.667 × 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg × 9 × 10¹⁶ m²/s²
K ≈ 1.114 × 10⁻¹⁰ kg m²/s²

The energy of the proton beam when it hits the target is approximately 1.114 × 10⁻¹⁰ Joules.
